abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings are as follows: Project
            outcome is satisfactory; sustainability is highly likely;
            institutional development impact is substantial; Bank
            performance is satisfactory; and Borrower performance is
            satisfactory. The Portfolio Development Project was a very
            unusual operation implemented in a very unusual Borrower
            during a very specific time period. Hence, lessons learned
            do not lend themselves easily for formulation if one
            attempts to draw conclusions potentially applicable to new
            projects in Russia, let alone other countries. Nevertheless,
            the key lessons learned from the Portfolio Development
            Project are outlined as follows:  1) The reasons behind such
            painfully slow start-up to Russian projects have varied, but
            eventually these particular projects not only improved but
            in fact turned into success stories. It seems that patience
            and flexibility exhibited by the Bank may work wonders for
            some projects. In retrospect, in this particular project it
            has worked apparently once the critical mass of ownership of
            the Project accumulated circa 1997. The PDL started to
            perform only when the right team was assembled in FCPF with
            very strong leadership. 2) A new institution building
            project may succeed provided, among other things, that a
            capable, well connected and strong manager is identified,
            whose commitment to the project is clearly above average and
            who has skills that are normally required for crisis
            management. If this is not the case then the risks to the
            sustainability of the project increase exponentially.  3)
            Decentralization of task management benefits a project. 4)
            The supervision requirements, especially for documentation,
            are very much geared towards a typical model of task
            management from Washington with regular supervision
            missions. When the task team is permanently in the field
            project issues are being resolved on the daily basis and,
            hence, recording of these project developments in formal
            aide-memoires tend to seem like a somewhat artificial and
            superficial burden. Perhaps an alternative arrangement to
            record the status of such project could be offered.  5)
            Fiscal sustainability of a new entity is a key foundation
            for success of an institution-building project, especially
            if an entity created is not supposed to or cannot be, for
            various reasons, financed from the regular budget. The
            solution for this Project, though again perhaps not easily
            replicable, but certainly an effective one was to provide to
            the Federal Center for Project Finance  (FCPF) a building in
            the center of Moscow. The building is a major source of
            revenues to cover FCPF's operating costs and thus an
            important factor behind the sustainability of the project.
